title: Triggers & Responses
description: Understand what activates your attachment system and how you respond.

questions.text: What triggers my attachment anxiety most?
choices: Not hearing from you when expected
Sensing something's wrong but you won't share

therapeutic.rationale: Attachment anxiety triggers reveal core vulnerabilities. Pulling-away triggers abandonment; no-contact triggers uncertainty; hidden-something triggers exclusion; change-triggers fear instability. Knowing your specific triggers helps you name them when activated rather than react blindly.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different anxiety triggers need different reassurance. The pulling-away trigger needs pursuit; the no-contact trigger needs communication. Provide specific reassurance for your partner's trigger.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared anxiety triggers mean similar vulnerabilities. You understand each other's anxiety because you share it. Be careful not to trigger your shared vulnerability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What triggers your attachment anxiety? What happens in your body when triggered? How do you typically respond?

questions.text: When I'm triggered, my typical response is to:
choices: Pursue closeness to feel secure again

therapeutic.rationale: Triggered responses reveal attachment coping. Pursuers have anxious activation; withdrawers have avoidant activation; anxious-reassurance seekers are overtly activated; communicators have secure response skills. Recognizing your trigger response is the first step to choosing differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trigger responses create predictable dances. The pursuer chases the withdrawer, who retreats further. Name the pattern when you're both triggered.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trigger responses can amplify or support. Two pursuers may chase each other; two withdrawers may both disappear. Know your shared pattern.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When triggered, what do you do? Does this response help or hurt? What would a healthier response look like?

questions.text: What helps me recover when my attachment is activated?
choices: Reassurance from you that we're okay
Time and space to settle my nervous system

therapeutic.rationale: Recovery support needs reveal soothing pathways. Reassurance-seekers need explicit confirmation; space-needers need time; understanding-seekers need cognitive clarity; physical-comfort seekers need touch. Knowing what helps your partner recover helps you provide exactly the right support.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different recovery needs guide support. The reassurance-seeker may feel dismissed by space-giving; the space-needer may feel smothered by reassurance pursuit. Ask: 'What do you need?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared recovery needs make support intuitive. You know what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you recover when activated? What makes it worse? Does your partner know how to help?

questions.text: How aware am I of my attachment patterns?
choices: Very aware - I can name them in the moment
Somewhat aware - I notice after the fact

therapeutic.rationale: Pattern awareness reflects attachment growth. In-the-moment namers have metacognitive skills; after-the-fact noticers are building awareness; learning-recognizers are in active growth; still-discoverers are beginning. Awareness is the foundation for changeâ€”you can't change what you can't see.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different awareness levels need patience. The in-the-moment namer may need to slow down for the still-discoverer. Both are on valid paths.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared awareness levels mean similar growth stages. You can learn and grow together at your shared pace.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How aware are you of your attachment patterns? What has increased your awareness? What would help you see more clearly?

questions.text: What do I need from you when I'm in a triggered state?
choices: Patience while I work through it

therapeutic.rationale: Triggered support needs vary by attachment style. Patience-needers need time; active-engagement seekers need pursuit; space-without-personal allows self-regulation; physical-presence provides safety without demand. Your partner is telling you exactly how to support them when triggered.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggered support needs guide response. The active-engagement seeker may feel abandoned by space-giving; the space-needer may feel overwhelmed by active pursuit. Know what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared triggered support makes helping intuitive. You know what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When triggered, what do you need from your partner? Have you told them clearly? What would ideal support look like?
